item.title: Todd Howard says Bethesda isn't 'fully ignoring' AI
item.content:encoded:
Diego Argüello,

Contributing Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

February 19, 2026

3 Min Read

Image via Bethesda Softworks

Bethesda game director Todd Howard said the studio isn’t “fully ignoring” AI, mentioning possible use cases outside of creative tasks.

In an interview during The Kinda Funny Gamecast yesterday, Howard shared some insights on the Xbox-owned studio's views around generative AI, a technology that has carried a negative reception from developers during the past few years, with many arguing that it is having a negative impact on the industry.

”For us, we’re being incredibly cautious,” Howard said. “[We’re] kind of viewing [it] as a tool, like an analyst, to look at the data in our games. We’re not using it to generate anything. I think there’s an element of artistic intention that is essential to what we do and what others do.

The game director went on to remark that “human intention is what makes things special,” and that’s “where we want to be.” Currently, it seems the interest is on using AI around big data tasks as well as “long-term player analysis.”

Related:Ishtar Games told to pay damages for illegally terminating workers

According to Howard, the technology can’t be ignored. “You can’t ignore it, in terms of it’s coming, it’s changing, every few months there’s a new model, particularly in the tech side with code or productivity or other things.”

He continued: “I would just say that we’re looking at that stuff, we’re not fully ignoring it, because where it can help us get better at some big data tasks that just take us a lot of time, that we just wish were done now, so we can move on to the creative stuff, that’s kinda where our heads are.”

Bethesda joins a growing list of studios under Xbox that have spoken about the use of AI, a technology that the company isn’t exactly ignoring. In August of last year, Xbox touted the new console's “AI-powered features” that will “enhance gameplay,” albeit without providing examples.

In 2025 alone, Activision Blizzard used AI to generate promotional images of games that didn’t exist. Then, Compulsion Games said that generative AI usage is “not mandated” at Xbox, while adding that it is “probably not the studio that will use AI the most.”

In July, a report indicated that Candy Crush maker King, also under the Xbox banner, had laid off around 200 employees. Some of those employees had been allegedly replaced by the internal AI tools they had designed themselves.

A month later, another report suggested that Microsoft had issued an AI mandate for King. According to anonymous sources at the time, Microsoft’s goal for workers during 2024 was reportedly in the 70 to 80 percent daily usage of AI on general tasks. The sources claimed that the goal for 2025 was to get up to 100 percent, so that every developer, including managers, would have to use AI daily.

Related:Lyrical Games announces full-financing publishing deal with The Chinese Room

According to one of the sources, at the time, AI adoption was “very low” apart from ChatGPT, and that King leadership is generally “quite AI skeptic.”

Then, in September, developer leads at ZeniMax Online Studios said the team “doesn’t really use” generative AI, while recognizing Microsoft’s interest in the technology.

”I mean, obviously we’ve looked into it,” studio game director Rich Lambert said at the time. “Microsoft has got their big push for AI. But we don’t really use a lot of it right now. I use a lot of it for meeting summaries and whatnot, because it just makes my life easier. It helps organize my inbox and stuff like that. But we don’t have a ton of it right now.”
